slideInfo.title: Geographic Features of Europe: Mountain Ranges

pButton.Name: Pyrenees
pButton.popInfo: The Pyrenees mountains form a political as well as a geographical boundary between Spain and France. The mountains also isolate the Iberian Peninsula from the rest of Europe.

pButton.Name: Alps
pButton.popInfo:
The Alps are an important chain of mountains which isolates Switzerland from northern Europe. In the past, they have served as a boundary between cultures and languages. Its mountain passes have also been important in military history.

Rousseau, an 18th century philosopher you will learn about in AP European History, once called the Alps, “The triumph of nature over the horrors of civilization.”

pButton.Name: Urals
pButton.popInfo: The Urals are considered a natural boundary between Europe and Asia. They run roughly north and south through western Russia.

pButton.Name: Carpathian Mts.
pButton.popInfo: The source of several important rivers, such as the Vistula, the Carpathian Mountains form a natural border between Poland and Slovakia.

pButton.Name: Kjolen Mts.
pButton.popInfo: The Kjolen Mountains dominate Norway and western Sweden. The apex of these mountains is nearly 7,000 feet high.

pButton.Name: Balkan Mts.
pButton.popInfo: Serbia and Bulgaria are just two countries that contain ranges of the Balkan Mountains. Perhaps the most well-known range runs through Greece and contains Mount Olympus.
